title: Asim Umar, The Indian-Born Chief Of Al-Qaeda In South Asia, Killed In Afghanistan
text:
Asim Umar, the head of the Al-Qaeda in South Asia was killed in a joint operation the Afghan and US forces, Afghan authorities have said.

According to the National Directorate of Security (NDS), Umar was killed in a raid on a Taliban compound in Helmand province on 23 September.

NDS also stated that six others were also killed along with him in the raid.

The NDS described Umar as a Pakistani citizen, like the others who were also killed in the same operation.

Though Umar held Pakistani citizenship, he was born in Sambhal, in Uttar Pradesh. He had reportedly migrated to Pakistan in the 1990s and later acquired citizenship there.

There is hardly any information available on his early activities, it is said that he was a student at Darul Uloom Haqqania in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, which is also known as the University of Jihad. This is the same Madrassa that many top commanders of the Taliban and other Pakistani jihadist groups have studied.

He was shot into prominence in September 2014 after Ayman Al-Zawahiri announced the creation of the Al-Qaeda in the Indian subcontinent and appointed him as its leader.

Ever since he has been featured in several video messages of the outfit. He was believed to be moving between Pakistan and Afghanistan for years to evade the security forces.

The killing of Umar in a Taliban compound also comes at a time when the US is trying to get a deal with the armed insurgent group to end its longest-running war.

Just last month the two sides had come close to striking a deal, but a secret meeting with the Taliban leadership and US President Donald Trump was called off at the last moment after the insurgents carried out an attack that also killed a US soldier.
